sp.p: Hear me, my good men of the mountains; hearken! A long ſtory I ſhall not tell you, for I am not fond of talking; and becauſe I hate lying I will tell you no ſtory at all.—This ſame Lazarra is a foreign ſcoundrel, a ſtranger to our nation, and no Swiſs. He has no buſineſs here: What does he come for? I'll tell you what—for plunder—to drive you out of your cabins, as he has drove the worthy Lord of Thurn out of his caſtle—Will you ſuffer it?

sp.speaker: MOUNTAINEER.
sp.p: No, no, we will not—we'll revenge Lord Albert.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: I knew you wou'd; I knew you were true Swiſs, and wou'd not let thoſe villainous interlopers tread in your lovely ſnows, and track your pleaſant mountains, where nothing grows but icicles and liberty.—Lord love you, you remember poor old Wolf; you have the ſteam of the caſtle kitchen ſtill in your noſtrils, and know I was not the Wolf at the door to keep you out, but to invite you in—You bear all this in mind; I know you do.

sp.speaker: MOUNTAINEER.
sp.p: We do, my maſter, therefore ſay no more, but march!

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Oh yes; I'll march—Lazarra pays the piper, ſo ſtrike up! We hav'nt got the true ſtep, but no matter: We'll trot, and our enemies ſhall gallop.

div.stage: (PHILIP is ſeen aſcending from the Subterranean. He aſſiſts Lord ALBERT, and they come forward.)

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, where are you? reach your hand; I've found the paſſage; the freſh air ſalutes us, and the bright moon ſubſcribes her friendly beam.—Welcome to liberty.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: My brave deliverer, come to my heart.

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p:
It is the proudeſt aim of my ambition to be near your heart. But you are faint, the ſubterranean damps hang on you ſtill. Within this
cave you'll find repoſe and ſhelter; enter it, my Lord. I will aſcend the heighths, kindle a fire, and bring the mountaineers to your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Thanks, gallant youth! a faintneſs ſteals upon me; I muſt confeſs to you I need repoſe.—Ah, Philip, to be torn from thoſe we love dearer than life, and in the hour of danger, by ſtrong neceſſity driven to deſert them, judge how it wrings my heart!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: I do—I judge, I feel it by my own.—No more, but enter. (ALBERT enters the Hermit's cave.) Oh Eloiſa; 'tis thy cauſe no leſs than Albert's, that gives wings to my impatience.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Here is my cell. We'll take a ſhort repoſe, and then reſume our flight.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: And wilt thou ſuffer all this for me? Wilt thou for me exhauſt the ſmall remains of ſtrength that age has left thee; thou pure benevolence, thou more than parent to poor deſerted Eloiſa?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: I'll not permit thee to deſpond, my child. There is a Providence, that bear me up above my body's ſtrength in thy protection. I feel as if I were again a father, and my loſt daughter liv'd again in thee: fear nothing then: within this peaceful cell thou wilt find viands of your own beſtowing.—Enter!—What ails thee?— There is nothing there; no dying man to fright thee.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Ah, he's there! the very man. I ſee him there— Lord Albert, ſtretcht on the floor, and dying, as it ſeems.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Merciful Heaven defend us! who is this?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Be not thus caſt in wonder. I am Albert, not dying, as ſhe thinks, but ſav'd from death, if you betray me not.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: If we betray you! we are not thoſe that wou'd betray the wretch that fled from juſtice to invoke protection; how then ſhou'd we betray the good Lord Albert, the patron of the needy and oppreſt, the orphan's father and the widow's friend? Bleſt be the hand that reſcued thee from death! Say who it was, that I may pray for him.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Philip of Belmont.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Oh approving Heaven, crown him, reward him for the glorious deed. My Philip has preſerv'd you; I acquit him. I was in like extremity with you at the ſame hour; I call'd him to my reſcue in vain; his virtue triumph'd o'er his love. He turn'd from me and ſav'd his benefactor. I praiſe him, I applaud him for the choice: you had a huſband's and a father's claim; for you the hearts of thouſands wou'd have bled; for me none other than his own.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Ah, father, if you knew the Lord of Thurn.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: I hope he has been taught to know himſelf in his adverſity.—I knew his father.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for it, if you knew him rightly; for then you know what cauſe I have to bluſh, when I am falſely ſtil'd the Lord of Thurn.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: That to confeſs beſpeaks a candid mind; for that I honour you; but Thurn is loſt. What then remains?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Before to-morrow's dawn either to ſee Lazarra at my feet, or ſee the light no more: if on the walls my banner flies, it flies not for myſelf, but for the daughter of that rightful Lord, who in his baniſhment was baſely murder'd.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Alas, that daughter never will be found, nor was that father murder'd; he yet lives, and I am he. Yes, Albert, I, I am that wretched father; degraded, exil'd, and at once bereft of wife, ſon, daughter; outcaſt of the world; no home, no country, not one friend on earth, ſave this ſweet innocent, the feeble ſtaff of an old beggar tottering to his grave.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Oh heavenly juſtice, how did I eſcape, whilſt you was begging at that caſtle's gate, which I, unconſcious of your right, uſurp'd?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: That I am Theodore, the baniſht Lord of Thurn and its domain, I had in proof to ſhew one relick, which the robbers miſs'd, my creſt (a crowned lion) cut in ruby; but this laſt pledge I left in Guntram's hands for purpoſes, which this dear child can witneſs.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: There needs no witneſs to the truth you utter; and here, in preſence of high Heaven, I ſwear to pay you homage, and reſtore your right.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: No, no, your virtues have aton'd to juſtice; you, Albert, have the bleſſings of the poor: Had I poſſeſſion, what cou'd I have more? I have no daughter; the inhuman villains, that robb'd and left me dying, kill'd my child. Within that cell I have preſerv'd one relick, one mournful relick. —You ſhall ſee my ſtore.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: I ſaw no relick. What does he allude to?

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Alas! I know not. My heart melts with pity.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: This mourful ſtory is not new to you.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: My Lord, I've often aſk'd, but never heard it: he always put me by when I made ſuit to ſhare his ſorrows—but behold he comes.

div.stage: HERMIT returns with a bloody mantle.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p:
This, this is all that's left me of my daughter;
this garment purpled as you ſee with blood.— Here ſtream'd that life-blood than my own more dear; and tho' my tears have almoſt blanch'd the ſpots, they cannot waſh away the deep remembrance of my afflicting loſs.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Oh agonizing ſight!

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Unhappy father, what can I do for thee?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Nothing for me: childleſs and old, forgetting this vain world, and by the world forgotten, for myſelf I only aſk a grave—but for this innocent whom I have ſnatcht from miſery, and who clings, as if by nature's charter, to my heart—for her I make appeal to your protection, and as in honour you ſhall deal with her, ſo may Heaven deal forgiveneſs to your father.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: She is my care henceforth; and would to Heaven, when thus I take her hand in pledge of faith, 'twas in my power to ſay—Behold your daughter.

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: That is the damſel; ſeize and take her hence.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Heaven! ſhew thy mercy!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Villains! looſe your hold!

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p:
Shall I not take my own? She is my wife: Away with her!—Lord Albert, ſtand aſide; I've
done you more than wrong enough already: beſides, you are unarm'd.

div.stage: (She is forced off by DARBONY's ſoldiers.)

sp.speaker: ELOISA
sp.p: Philip! Philip!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Stop! ſtop! A reſcue!

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: Stop thy clamorous tongue, grey-headed hypocrite. March on, my hearts!

sp.speaker: ELOISA
sp.p: Philip! Philip!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: 'Tis Eloiſa's voice! Friends! brethren! follow.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Follow! the vengeance! I have burſt my heart with following; and that madcap, Philip, leads them off at ſcore. Holloa! who's that? My noble maſter living! Here! here's a ſword; carve for yourſelf, and ſpare not: firſt come, firſt ſerv'd; no ceremony at this ſport.

div.stage: (ALBERT and WOLF follow to the fight.)

sp.speaker: HERMIT
sp.p: There, there they go! and now the wood conceals them: now they come out; ſee! ſee! they're cloſe upon them! they meet! they fight! Philip has conquer'd! Hark! our people ſhout: the coward miſcreants throw away their arms, and beg for mercy. Hah! ſhe lives! ſhe lives!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Joy! triumph! victory! Eloiſa's ſav'd!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: My child! my child! Oh, welcome to my ſight! My old heart bounds with tranſport to behold thee.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Bring in your priſoner; we have got their leader.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Let me come to him; I've had a taſte of his ſword, now he ſhall have a belly full of mine.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Hold! hold! 'tis Darbony; he ſpar'd my life: I'll not take his.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: But I will for you; that will do as well.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Forbear! thou art too bloody.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: You ſee I am: he has drawn my blood; why ſhould not I open a vein for him?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Stand off, and quit him! What is your pretence for ſeizing this young woman?

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: If I had ſeiz'd her, and ſecur'd my prize, I ſhould have had a title, Lord of Thurn, ſuperior to your own.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: What do you mean? Is ſhe not Guntram's daughter?

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: I am your priſoner; you have ſav'd my life: therefore I tell you fairly, not one drop of Guntram's blood runs in thoſe noble veins: I would not treat with him till he confeſs'd it. I marry Guntram's daughter!—no! He ſtole her, like a thief: ſhe is the daughter of Theodore, the ancient Lord of Thurn; and had I married her—

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Break off! the father, the father ſtands before you!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Oh! my daughter!

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Philip, ſupport me! bear me to his feet, that I may kneel.—Oh! tell me, tell me truly, if it was nature's inſtinct that inſpir'd me to love thee, honour thee, and call thee father?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! how wonderful art thou in mercy! I'm loſt: the bleſſing is too vaſt for me; my weak frame totters: lead me to my cell.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: How's this, old friend? A tear on that rough cheek?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Yes, a rough tear; not one of your ſoft drops, that whimpering pity ſheds: I never weep, except for joy that honeſt men are happy. Come, ſignor Darbony, enter the cell: you are not overburden'd with humanity; a few more leſſons of this ſort won't hurt you.

div.stage: SCENE, a Defile in the Neighbourhood of Thurn Caſtle; ALBERT, PHILIP, HERMIT, ELOISA, WOLF, and SOLDIERS.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: NOW, Comrades, mark where the declining moon, propitious to our enterprize, withdraws her fading creſcent! The dark hour comes on, and warns us to the charge!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: We are all ready: our mountaineers are ambuſh'd within call. Where ſhall we ſtorm?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Upon the weſtern flank: the moat is fordable, and the wall weakeſt there: he has ſecured the bridge.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: I wiſh we had done as much before he paſs'd it; but rogues are wiſer in their generation than we dull downright fellows are in ours.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Ah, Philip, my whole heart is ſick with dread of what has paſs'd within the caſtle.

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: We ſhall ſoon have the caſtle.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Shall we have the lives within it? Shall I greet my wife? Shall I embrace my ſon?

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Diſmiſs theſe terrors, and repoſe your hope where you have lodged your faith. Draw forth your ſword! We cannot fail to conquer when thoſe we combat are the foes of Heaven!

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: 'Tis done. Now, heroes, follow to the charge!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: A moment's patience. Where ſhall we beſtow this aged father, and his defenceleſs daughter?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Wolf, you are wounded; you ſhall ſtay behind: there lives not one more worthy of that truſt.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: There lives not one leſs likely to perform it; for though I have a reverence for old age, and a ſoft ſide towards innocence and beauty, yet if I hear the claſh of ſwords in battle, I muſt, perforce, turn out and make one with them: therefore let me be foremoſt in the onſet, and laſt in the retreat—there is my poſt.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p:
I will not hold one hero from his duty; and,
though I can no longer wield a ſword, behold I have a weapon— (ſhows a dagger). This, and the darkneſs of the night, will guard us, therefore, go forth, and conquer.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: There is an arbour (Philip knows the ſpot) of nature's making, in the cheſnut grove, beſide the weſtern tower; there we may paſs the anxious minutes, and put up our prayers for your ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Eſcort them to the place! We, the mean while, will martial our brave band, and for our wives, our children, and our altars, aſſur'd of conqueſt, we ruſh upon the foe!

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment in the Caſtle of Thurn.
div.p:
The monſter will not let me ſee my child— Well! Heaven's high will be done—There was a time when my afflicted ſpirit was prepar'd to die with Albert! But laſt night in ſilence I commun'd with my heart, and heard a voice that ſeem'd to cry within me— "Hold thine hand, creature of God! thy life is not thine own, and none but he that gave can take away"— I ſtarted; left my couch; my lamp was burning; the book of life was open on my table; I read; the text was—patience—and the word of inſpiration ſunk into my heart with influence ſo perſuaſive, ſo ſerene, that as I read, I reaſoned, and perceived when Heaven is pleaſed to puniſh,
'tis our part to ſuffer and ſubmit.—Eugene, approach!
Is there not ſomething ſtirring in the caſtle that occupies my tyrant, and reprieves me from his deteſted preſence?

sp.speaker: EUGENE.
sp.p: I think there is—Scouts are for ever paſſing, that ſcour the country round; the walls are manned; in all the watch towers centinels are poſted, and by what is going forward, I ſhould ſuppoſe he looks to be attack'd.

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Alas! what can my helpleſs people do, when their brave leader's loſt, and Wolf is killed, and Philip is far off?

sp.speaker: EUGENE.
sp.p: Of Philip I know nothing; but for Wolf, I muſt believe he lives, and that I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Boy, you're deceived; let me not hear of hope, ſave what the cheering recollection gives, that all the ſufferings of this tranſient life muſt have a ſpeedy end: of this aſſur'd, I am prepar'd, for conſcience ſake, to brave all that Lazarra's fury can inflict to ſhake my honour, or ſubdue my ſpirit; for 'tis no queſtion with me whom to fear—him, a contemptible and ſhort-liv'd tyrant, that only can afflict me for awhile, or that tremendous judge whoſe juſt award is happineſs or miſery without end.

sp.speaker: EUGENE.
sp.p: She's gone, and knows not yet the full extent of her affliction—When ſhe ſhall be told, Lord Albert fell not in the field of battle, but butchered by aſſaſſins in the dungeon of his own Belmont, what will then ſupport her? Will ſighs and tears relieve her ſad deſpair? Oh they wou'd! I'd weep my eyes to water.

lg.l: "To ſigh when ſorrow loads the breaſt
"To weep is almoſt to be bleſt
"Sigh then, ſad dame, if ſighs may cheer

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Saxon Hall.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Albert, ere this, is dead! Where is Joanna? The ſpark of pity that was quick within me, her inſolent defiance has extinguiſhed; my temper and my time are both exhauſted; let her be ſummoned, and at once determine for life or death, my victim or my bride!—Do you hear me, ſluggards? Which of you has charge upon the weſtern flank?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: I have, an' pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: It does not pleaſe me, ſir—the wall is open. Why is the breach not ſtopt, as I directed?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: We had no hands to ſpare from other duty.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: No, they were all employ'd upon your trenchers; you are greedy feeders all, but lazy workers. Why did you not ſet the priſoners upon it?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: The moat is fordable; we dare not truſt them.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: If the moat 's fordable, where's our defence, the wall being left in breach? 'Tis well for us that Albert is not living.—Now, what news?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: My lord, 'tis ſaid that Darbony is taken.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Who ſays it? Who has taken him?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: The fellow that was in the fight reports, Lord Albert took him priſoner.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: That is a lie as deep as to the center—Albert is dead; here's one that will confirm it: You come from Wenſel?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER.
sp.p: I do, my lord, from Belmont; I am ſent with humble greetings to you from my maſter.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Does Wenſel ſend me Albert's head withal? If he does that, his greeting will be welcome.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER.
sp.p: Alas, my lord, I am compell'd to ſay that Albert has eſcap'd.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Infamous traitor! Wenſel ſhall feel my vengeance! Sound to arms! Albert eſcap'd; and Darbony a priſoner! Call out the garriſon, and man the ramparts! I'll have the priſoners put to inſtant death!

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: Arm! arm, my lord! The caſtle is aſſaulted! Your people fly! —Arm, arm, or all is loſt!

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Where 's the aſſault?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: Upon the weſtern flank:—they have paſs'd the moat!—they are within the walls!

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p:
Well, ſally from the bridge, and cut them
off! Sound, ſound a charge! and follow to the bridge!

div.stage: (JOANNA ruſhes in, ſtops, liſtens in an attitude of horror and alarm; then exclaims—)

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Horror! Confuſion! Whither ſhall I fly?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Fly! Never think of flying, noble lady:— Your huſband lives! he fights! he conquers!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Lives! Does my Albert live! May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: To be ſure you may; Lazarra flies before him! The caſtle is our own! The priſoners are ſet free!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: All gracious Heaven! what thanks ſhall I repay thee?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: As many as you will hereafter; the fewer the better juſt at preſent; follow me, and ſhew yourſelf to your defenders; they'll fight like devils when they are led on by you. Come on! a Montfaucon is born to conquer!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: And I will conquer, or expire with Albert!

div.stage: SCENE, a broken and pictureſque Country.—On the Flank, the Bower where the HERMIT and ELOISA are concealed.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: You may come forth, my child, the ſtorm is over.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Look, father, look; the clouds, that threaten'd us with burſts of thunder, now have roll'd away; and the ſun riſes red upon the mountains, a rayleſs ball of fire!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: So gleam'd his orb on that diſaſtrous morn, when waking from my trance I gaz'd around with wild amaze in ſearch of thee, and found thy bloody garment by the robbers left—Source of unnumber'd ſorrows — Yet, behold, Heaven ſmiles upon the evening of my days—So, when this fearful conflict ſhall be over, the ſetting ſun may beam ſerene on thee, and Philip cloſe his triumphs in thy arms.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Ah, my dear father, what is that I ſee?—Turn, turn your eyes, and tell me who are thoſe that iſſue from the caſtle, and now they paſs the bridge, and now they fight!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p:
By all that's terrible it is Lazarra! He ſallies on the aſſailants— Heaven and earth! can thoſe be Swiſs that fly? Are thoſe my countrymen
that turn their backs upon a foreign foe? Fly to your covert! Fly, my ſweet child! The battle gathers towards you!

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: I'll follow you, my father, but my heart is in the fight with Philip—Heaven protect him!

div.stage: (The Battle.—Different Diviſions are ſeen fighting between the Cliffs.—PHILIP appears rallying his Party.)

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Once more, my gallant countrymen, once more charge, and you conquer! See, their battle 's broke; they reel, they ſtagger—Victory invites you. Philip of Belmont leads you to the charge.

div.stage: (WENSEL, purſued by ALBERT, flies to PHILIP, who preſents himſelf to ALBERT, covering the Fugitive.)

sp.speaker: WENSEL.
sp.p: Oh! ſave me, Philip, ſave me, or I periſh!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Stop thy avenging hand, heroic chief, nor through my filial boſom paſs thy ſword—Remember Belmont, and for my ſake ſpare him —He is my father.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p:
I'll not kill thy father—Live, wretch, but never let me ſee thee more:—Fly to the rocks, and bid them cover thee, for the ſun ſickens to behold thy ſhame. (WENSEL retires.)
Now, Philip, forward! Lo, where brave old Wolf comes pouring down from his embattled heights to ſnatch the victory from us—Forward! forward!

div.stage: (WOLF is ſeen engaged; his Opponents fly; he advances.)

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Well done, my cat-o'-mountains, never ſpare 'em; out with your claws, and briſtle up your backs; the raſcals dare not look upon your eyes, they glare ſo terribly; tear 'em and eat 'em. What between Wolf and Cat they 've had a bargain; I 've ſet my fangs in ſome of them with a vengeance.

What ſculker have we here? Come out—Thou villain! thou cutpurſe! who made thee a ſoldier, ſirrah? Nature intended thee for an attorney—Come, bruſh your memory up, mumble a prayer, and be quick! Thou 'rt hardly worth the time 'twill take to kill thee.

sp.speaker: GUNTRAM.
sp.p: Spare me, brave Wolf! Behold, here is a ring, the ſignet of Lord Albert, for my ſafeguard— Examine it, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: WOLF
sp.p: Raſcal, thou lieſt, thou pettifogging knave; this is not Albert's ſignet—thou haſt ſtolen it.
sp.stage: (Looks for GUNTRAM, who has eſcaped the meanwhile)
sp.p:
Hah! gone, abſconded, taken a French leave! The devil follow him! he's not worth the catching
—I'll kill the next I meet inſtead of him.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: I'll fly no further. Here I fix my foot, and if my ſoldiers will deſert their leader, I've nothing but my ſingle life to fight for, and that I'll ſell as dearly as I may to him that bids for it— Albert!—

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Lazarra! I've ſought you.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: You have found me.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Twice conquer'd, you have forfeited your title to the fair treatment of a loyal knight, for you have broke the truce you ſwore to, and, like a robber in the dead of night, forc'd my unguarded caſtle; conquer'd now, and all retreat cut off, you're at my mercy—Deliver up your ſword, and aſk your life.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: To me theſe terms! You little know Lazarra. I forc'd your caſtle—true; for in your caſtle there dwelt a lady, whom you dar'd to marry in violation of the laws of honour.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Honour! You ought not to pronounce the name.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: What was your honour when you fled your caſtle, and left Joanna in your rival's power?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Joanna's purity defies your power.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: I ſuffer none to live that dare defy it. One triumph I have had, one yet remains—to vanquiſh thee, and perfect my revenge.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Demon incarnate! to your native hell thus I devote you. Do you feel me now?

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: As the chaf'd lion does, to rage the fiercer— (They fight. ALBERT, in parrying LAZARRA's thruſt, ſtumbles at the root of a tree, and falls.) There, there! bleſt fortune!—thy ſtar falls to earth, mine keeps its ſphere.—Now thou art at my mercy.

div.stage: (Stands over him, and points his ſword at his breaſt.)

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: I ſcorn your mercy. Strike!

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Expect it; but firſt take this truth from me— Joanna lives; you, the mean time, a ſolitary ghoſt, muſt wait her coming in thoſe gloomy ſhades to which I now diſmiſs thee.

div.stage: (As LAZARRA is in the act of killing ALBERT, JOANNA ruſhes in, utters a ſcream of horror, and ſtrikes LAZARRA to the heart, who falls with the ſtroke.)

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Ah, thou murderer! Hence to thoſe ſhades thyſelf! Behold, 'tis done—He faints, he falls, he dies—Save me, ſupport me! Oh Philip, tell me, does my Albert live?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: He lives, he lives, he claſps thee to his heart; thou angel of his reſcue.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Yes, 'twas a timely reſcue o' my conſcience— How came you, Sir, to fall under his ſword?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: The ground deceiv'd me as I gave back from him.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Aye, that fame giving back is a bad practice; but he has got his paſſport; he is off.

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Look, look! he dies; convulſion ſhakes his frame; he gaſps, he writhes in anguiſh, he expires!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Judge of all hearts, oh take him to thy mercy! He dies without a pray'r.—Horrible ſight!—What Heaven inſpir'd me with the ſtrength to do, now, having done, I tremble to behold.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p:
Take hence the body! Sound a retreat, and call in the purſuers! Now to the caſtle—'Tis Joanna's triumph, and we will grace it with our beſt diſplay. To all my friends and brave defenders, thanks! Actions muſt ſpeak my feelings;
time muſt ſhew what my full heart conceives, for language cannot. Philip, behold our venerable Hermit; and in his hand, like Truth led on by Time, thy deſtin'd bride approaches.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Albert, if every conqueror had a cauſe worthy as your's, we ſhou'd rejoice in conqueſts; but in this world, for reaſons only known to Heaven, bad men will triumph for a time, and be the lords and arbiters of fortune. You are both good and proſperous, and your candour in owning me the rightful Lord of Thurn, cancels your father's wrongs; but what you riſqu'd your life to gain for life you ſhall poſſeſs. Give Philip Belmont, and I'll give him her, that wou'd convert a cottage to a palace—Take her, brave youth, ſhe's your's!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: With heart and ſoul grateful to Heaven and you, I ſeal my thanks upon this beauteous hand, and greet my bleſſing.

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: May years of happineſs attend you both!

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Hence may the raſh invaders of our land learn to revere the valour that defends it! Now let our gallant warriors raiſe their voices in celebration of this joyful day!

div.p: Printed by Luke Hanſard, Great Turnſtile, Lincoln's-Inn Fields.
